title: Why are airplanes slower than they used to be? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Why were supersonic flights, like the Concorde, restricted to mostly ocean routes?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to concerns about air traffic control.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they generated a continuous moving shockwave known as a sonic boom.

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of increased demand for flights after September 11th, 2001.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the high cost of fuel.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the biggest concerns when it comes to making commercial flights faster?

options.label: A
options.text: The high cost of fuel.

options.label: B
options.text: The environmental impact of increased speed.

options.label: C
options.text: The strain on airline staff due to increased flight times.

options.label: D
options.text: The potential for sonic booms to damage buildings.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to make an aircraft faster without burning lots of fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: By adjusting the wing sweep to bring the wings closer in.

options.label: B
options.text: By using alternative and synthetic fuels.

options.label: C
options.text: By extending the nose with a long spike to break the shockwave into smaller ones.

options.label: D
options.text: By using hybrid-electric planes.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Concorde become unsustainable and was retired in 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to decreased demand for flights after September 11th, 2001.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was too expensive for both airlines and passengers.

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of increased air traffic control restrictions.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to concerns about the environmental impact of supersonic flights.

multiple-choice.question: What may solve the energy efficiency problem with supersonic flights?

options.label: A
options.text: Modifying an aircraft's shape to reduce the impact of its sonic boom.

options.label: B
options.text: Using alternative and synthetic fuels.

options.label: C
options.text: Extending the nose with a long spike to break the shockwave into smaller ones.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: The counterintuitive way to be more persuasive - Niro Sivanathan

multiple-choice.question: What is the cognitive quirk that occurs when people are presented with a large amount of information, including both relevant and irrelevant details, which can dilute the perceived value of the information?

options.label: A
options.text: The confirmation bias

options.label: B
options.text: The dilution effect

options.label: C
options.text: The anchoring effect

options.label: D
options.text: The availability heuristic

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to rate Tim as having a higher GPA than Tom, despite both spending 31 hours a week outside of class?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Tim has more siblings

options.label: B
options.text: Because Tom has a brother and two sisters

options.label: C
options.text: Because the irrelevant information about Tom dilutes the diagnostic information about his study habits

options.label: D
options.text: Because Tim is more charismatic

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are exposed to both major and minor side effects of a pharmaceutical drug in an advertisement?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to rate the drug's overall severity as higher

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to be attracted to consuming the drug

options.label: C
options.text: They are less likely to be influenced by the advertisement

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to pay more for the drug

multiple-choice.question: What does the body of research suggest about the relationship between the quality and quantity of arguments in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: That increasing the quantity of arguments strengthens the case

options.label: B
options.text: That increasing the quality of arguments strengthens the case

options.label: C
options.text: That the quality of arguments trumps the quantity of arguments

options.label: D
options.text: That the quantity of arguments trumps the quality of arguments

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the speaker's research on the dilution effect in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are more likely to be influenced by persuasive messages that include both relevant and irrelevant information

options.label: B
options.text: That people are less likely to be influenced by persuasive messages that include both relevant and irrelevant information

options.label: C
options.text: That the delivery of a message is every bit as important as its content

options.label: D
options.text: That the content of a message is more important than the delivery

title: Can you solve the fantasy election riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that the Dormor Polling Agency faces while conducting a poll in the fantasy realm?

options.label: A
options.text: Many citizens are unwilling to admit their preference for the troll due to his controversial life choices.

options.label: B
options.text: The treefellow is not a well-known candidate, making it difficult to gather information.

options.label: C
options.text: The polling agency is understaffed and lacks resources.

options.label: D
options.text: The citizens of the realm are not interested in participating in the poll.

multiple-choice.question: What is the solution that the Dormor Polling Agency uses to conduct an accurate poll in the first scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: They ask every pollee to flip the coin twice and report their true preference if the result is not heads or tails.

options.label: B
options.text: They use a random sampling method to select respondents.

options.label: C
options.text: They use a coin toss to add random chance to the interaction, allowing troll supporters to deny their preference.

options.label: D
options.text: They conduct the poll in a different location to minimize bias.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Dormor Polling Agency adjust their method to conduct an accurate poll in the second scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: They ask every pollee to flip the coin once and report their true preference if the result is heads.

options.label: B
options.text: They use a different type of coin that has more than two possible outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: They ask every pollee to flip the coin twice and report their true preference if the result is not heads or tails.

options.label: D
options.text: They use a combination of coin tosses and random sampling to select respondents.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the poll in the second scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The treefellow wins the election by a margin of 55 to 45.

options.label: B
options.text: The troll wins the election by a margin of 55 to 45.

options.label: C
options.text: The election is a tie, with both candidates receiving 50% of the vote.

options.label: D
options.text: The poll is inconclusive, and a new election is held.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the coin in the context of the poll?

options.label: A
options.text: The coin is used to determine the winner of the election.

options.label: B
options.text: The coin is used to add random chance to the interaction, allowing respondents to deny their preference.

options.label: C
options.text: The coin is used to select respondents for the poll.

options.label: D
options.text: The coin is used to measure the margin of victory.

title: What’s the best fuel for your car?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is a challenge facing the development of carbon-neutral fuels?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive, and there are no environmental concerns.

options.label: B
options.text: They take up more space than an energetically equivalent amount of gasoline.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not available in many countries.

options.label: D
options.text: They require more maintenance than gas-powered cars.

title: What it takes to be racially literate - Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo's work in promoting racial literacy?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a national community where everyone is the same.

options.label: B
options.text: To educate people about the history of racism and its effects.

options.label: C
options.text: To raise the standards of racial literacy and create a shared American culture.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on individual experiences without considering systemic racism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "heart gap" in racial literacy, according to Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo?

options.label: A
options.text: The inability to understand systemic racism.

options.label: B
options.text: The inability to understand personal experiences of racism.

options.label: C
options.text: The inability to be compassionate and empathetic towards others.

options.label: D
options.text: The inability to recognize the pain of white supremacy and oppression.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo's work is different from traditional education on racism?

options.label: A
options.text: They focus solely on statistics and facts.

options.label: B
options.text: They use personal stories to illustrate the effects of racism.

options.label: C
options.text: They ignore the experiences of people who are not directly affected by racism.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not consider the historical context of racism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Cherokee language, according to Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a relic of the past and has no relevance today.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a symbol of white supremacy and oppression.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an act of survival and preservation of culture and history.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a language that is only spoken by a few people.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo's work?

options.label: A
options.text: That racism is not a problem in the United States.

options.label: B
options.text: That everyone is the same and we should not focus on differences.

options.label: C
options.text: That we need to raise the standards of racial literacy and create a shared American culture.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should ignore the experiences of people who are not directly affected by racism.

title: How would you finish the sentence, “Imagine if…”? - Sir Ken Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What is the key ability that sets humans apart from the rest of life on Earth?

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to bring into mind things that aren’t present.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to breathe underwater.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We can anticipate the future, revisit the past, and see things as other people see them.

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Imagination is only useful for anticipating the future.

title: Uncovering the brain's biggest secret - Melanie E. Peffer

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem that scientists faced when trying to study the brain's nervous system in the late 1800s?

options.label: A
options.text: They couldn't find the right microscope technology.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain tissue was too dense and difficult to work with.

options.label: C
options.text: They didn't have enough funding for their research.

options.label: D
options.text: They didn't have enough time to study the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the staining technique developed by Camillo Golgi in 1873 that allowed researchers to see the entire cell body of a neuron?

options.label: A
options.text: The "black reaction"

options.label: B
options.text: The "silver stain"

options.label: C
options.text: The "Golgi stain"

options.label: D
options.text: The "neuron stain"

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between Golgi's theory and Cajal's theory of how the nervous system works?

options.label: A
options.text: Golgi believed in a network of fibers, while Cajal believed in a linear chain of activation.

options.label: B
options.text: Golgi believed in a linear chain of activation, while Cajal believed in a network of fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Golgi believed in a web of tissue, while Cajal believed in a single cell.

options.label: D
options.text: Golgi believed in a single cell, while Cajal believed in a web of tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the theory that proposed the brain's tissue was made up of many discrete cells, instead of one connected tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: The "neuron doctrine"

options.label: B
options.text: The "reticular theory"

options.label: C
options.text: The "Golgi theory"

options.label: D
options.text: The "Cajal theory"

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Cajal's research that supported his hypothesis of how the nervous system works?

options.label: A
options.text: Electron microscopy revealed a membrane around each nerve cell keeping it separate from its neighbors.

options.label: B
options.text: Cajal's research showed that electrical signals travel uninterrupted across a network of fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Cajal's research showed that the brain's tissue is made up of one connected tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: Cajal's research showed that the neuron doctrine was incorrect.

title: Why didn’t this 2,000 year old body decompose? - Carolyn Marshall

multiple-choice.question: What was the Lindow Man, and how was his body preserved?

options.label: A
options.text: The Lindow Man was a body that was preserved in a tomb, and his body was well-preserved due to the dry conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: The Lindow Man was a body that was discovered in a bog outside Cheshire, England, and his body was preserved due to the acidic conditions of the bog.

options.label: C
options.text: The Lindow Man was a body that was mummified, and his body was preserved due to the dry conditions of the desert.

options.label: D
options.text: The Lindow Man was a body that was frozen, and his body was preserved due to the cold temperatures.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the Lindow Man's body was so well-preserved, despite being over 2,000 years old?

options.label: A
options.text: The dry conditions of the bog allowed for the body to decompose slowly.

options.label: B
options.text: The acidic conditions of the bog prevented most microbes from functioning, which allowed the body to remain intact.

options.label: C
options.text: The body was mummified, which preserved it for centuries.

options.label: D
options.text: The body was frozen, which prevented it from decomposing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of microbes in the decomposition process?

options.label: A
options.text: Microbes break down organic matter into smaller parts, releasing nutrients that can be used by plants.

options.label: B
options.text: Microbes absorb nutrients from organic matter and excrete the rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Microbes release enzymes that trigger a chemical reaction called oxidation, breaking down molecules of organic matter.

options.label: D
options.text: Microbes consume carbon and some nutrients, while excess molecules of nitrogen, sulfur, calcium, and more are left behind in the soil.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between environments that support more microbes and those that do not?

options.label: A
options.text: Environments that are hot and wet support more microbes than places that are cold and dry.

options.label: B
options.text: Environments that are cold and dry support more microbes than places that are hot and wet.

options.label: C
options.text: Environments that are complex support more microbes than places that are simple.

options.label: D
options.text: Environments that are simple support more microbes than places that are complex.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Lindow Man's discovery in the context of understanding the decomposition process?

options.label: A
options.text: The Lindow Man's discovery shows that decomposition is a slow process that takes centuries.

options.label: B
options.text: The Lindow Man's discovery demonstrates the importance of microbes in the decomposition process.

options.label: C
options.text: The Lindow Man's discovery reveals the role of acidic conditions in preserving organic matter.

options.label: D

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for avoiding false empathy when interacting with diverse others?

options.text: To rush into action without stopping to query the source of their distress.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the person's problem and focus on your own.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To put on your superhero cape and act without thinking.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the person's problem and focus on your own.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability that the human wins on the first try?

options.label: A
options.text: p

options.label: B
options.text: (1-minus-p) times q

options.label: C
options.text: p times (1-minus-p) times (1-minus-q)

options.text: p divided by 1-minus-q

options.label: A
options.text: p

options.label: B
options.text: (1-minus-p) times q

options.label: C
options.text: (1-minus-p) times (1-minus-q)

options.label: D
options.text: p divided by 1-minus-q

options.label: C
options.text: p divided by 1-minus-(1-minus-q)

options.label: D
options.text: p divided by 1-minus-p

options.label: A
options.text: p

options.label: C
options.text: p divided by 1-minus-p

options.label: D
options.text: p plus 1

options.label: C

title: These animals can hear everything - Jakob Christensen-Dalsgaard

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that owls can hear sounds that are too quiet for humans to detect?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They have ears positioned asymmetrically to help their brains determine the direction of the sound's source.

options.label: D

options.text: They are extremely small.

options.label: B
options.text: They are extremely sensitive to high-frequency noises.

options.label: C

options.text: They are extremely sensitive to low-frequency noises.

multiple-choice.question: How do baleen whales emit and detect sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: They emit sounds around 200,000 hertz and listen for the reflections.

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: They emit sounds around 14 hertz, the deepest among mammals, and get picked up by other baleen whales via their jawbones.
